croup.name: Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis)
croup.description: Viral infection causing inflammation of the larynx and upper airway, typically in children aged 6 months to 6 years

mild.criteria: Occasional barky cough, no stridor at rest, no/minimal chest wall retractions

moderate.criteria: Frequent barky cough, audible stridor at rest, visible chest wall retractions

severe.criteria: Frequent barky cough, prominent inspiratory stridor, marked chest wall retractions, agitation

dexamethasone.clinical_notes: Preferred first-line treatment. Single dose usually sufficient.

prednisolone.clinical_notes: Alternative to dexamethasone. Longer course required.

nebulized_adrenaline.clinical_notes: Reserved for moderate to severe croup. Temporary effect. Monitor for rebound symptoms.

clinical_pearls: Peak incidence in autumn and winter months
Most commonly caused by parainfluenza virus
Cool mist or humidified air may provide comfort
Avoid agitating the child during assessment
Consider bacterial tracheitis if high fever and toxic appearance

acute_asthma.name: Acute Asthma Exacerbation
acute_asthma.description: Acute worsening of asthma symptoms requiring immediate medical intervention in adults

mild.criteria: Able to speak in sentences, mild dyspnea, peak flow >70% predicted

moderate.criteria: Speaking in phrases, moderate dyspnea, peak flow 40-70% predicted

severe.criteria: Speaking in words only, severe dyspnea, peak flow <40% predicted

life_threatening.criteria: Unable to speak, exhaustion, altered consciousness, silent chest

salbutamol_nebulized.frequency: every 20 minutes for first hour, then hourly
salbutamol_nebulized.clinical_notes: Can be given continuously in severe cases. Monitor for tremor and tachycardia.

ipratropium_bromide.frequency: every 20 minutes for first hour, then every 4-6 hours
ipratropium_bromide.clinical_notes: Add to salbutamol nebulizer for moderate to severe exacerbations.

prednisolone.clinical_notes: Give early. No need to taper for 5-day course. Alternative: hydrocortisone 100mg IV q6h if unable to take orally.

magnesium_sulfate.clinical_notes: For severe exacerbations not responding to initial treatment. Monitor BP and deep tendon reflexes.

aminophylline.clinical_notes: Consider only if not responding to other therapies. Narrow therapeutic window. Monitor levels.

clinical_pearls: Triggers include allergens, infections, exercise, cold air, stress
Silent chest is an ominous sign indicating severe airflow limitation
Peak flow monitoring helps assess severity and response to treatment
Oxygen target 94-98% (or 88-92% if risk of hypercapnic respiratory failure)
Consider ICU if requiring >40% oxygen or deteriorating despite treatment
Always provide written asthma action plan on discharge
red_flags: Rising pCO2 or normal pCO2 in severe attack

copd_exacerbation.name: Acute Exacerbation of COPD
copd_exacerbation.description: Acute worsening of respiratory symptoms in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease requiring additional therapy

mild.criteria: Managed at home with increased bronchodilator use
mild.symptoms: increased symptoms but able to manage daily activities

moderate.symptoms: significant increase in symptoms, limitation of daily activities

severe.symptoms: marked increase in symptoms, unable to perform daily activities

salbutamol.clinical_notes: Can increase frequency in acute phase. Consider adding ipratropium.

ipratropium.clinical_notes: Often combined with salbutamol. Maximum benefit when used together.

prednisolone.clinical_notes: Short course without taper. Speeds recovery and reduces treatment failure.

amoxicillin.clinical_notes: For purulent sputum or increased sputum volume. Alternative: doxycycline 200mg stat then 100mg daily.

doxycycline.clinical_notes: Alternative antibiotic if penicillin allergic or local resistance patterns indicate.

co_amoxiclav.clinical_notes: For treatment failure or risk factors for resistant organisms.

clinical_pearls: Most exacerbations are triggered by respiratory infections (viral or bacterial)
Anthonisen criteria: increased dyspnea, sputum volume, sputum purulence
Oxygen target 88-92% to avoid hypercapnic respiratory failure
Consider NIV (BiPAP) for pH <7.35 or hypercapnic respiratory failure
Antibiotics indicated if purulent sputum or severe exacerbation
Review inhaler technique and provide smoking cessation advice
